free_txt: Data were compiled in SCJAD of Saratov
State University.
corrected  by  SD and VV:  Updated to new
date formats,  lower case,  ERR-ANALYS, PART-DET
deleted, STATUS added to SUBENTs 002 - 010, EN-SEC.

0.free_text: The  first  excited  state cross section.

free_txt: The normalization of neutron spectra was accomplished
by normalizing to an equal number of photons in  the
corresponding  bremsstrahlung intensity distribution
in a 50 keV wide bin at 9 MeV.
The ratio of the 2s1/2 to 1d5/2 configuration
amplitudes in the ground state of O-18 was obtained.
Data were  corrected for:
(a) the dead-time and
(b) the detector efficiency.
Photoneutron energy   spectra  from  O-18  have  been
measured at bremsstrahlung endpoint energies from 11
to  18 MeV in 1 MeV steps to obtain the ground state
cross section and  the  first  excited  state  cross
section
A  tank  of  liquid scintillator (NE213) 13 cm
thick by 36 cm in diam.  backed by 3 photomultiplier
tubes was used.
Statistical  errors  of measurements.
Energy resolution  of  spectrometer  was 10 keV at 2
MeV neutron energy and 200 keV  at  10  MeV  neutron
energy.
A 0.05 cm thick tungsten radiator was used.
Flight path = 50 m.
The  target  consisted  of a mylar
walled slab ,  0.60 cm thick,  containing 200  g  of
heavy water (D2O).  The oxygen was enriched to 98.7%
in O-18.
By the  compiler:  the  data in two regions from 1.00
MeV to 2.04 MeV and from 2.80 MeV to 5.40  MeV  were
read  from experimental points,  which were not able
to be resolved,  with the constant step of 0.13 MeV.
Main  features  of  the  experimental neutron energy
spectrum were conserved.
Data from Fig.5 of CJP,53,786,1975.
By the  compiler:  the  data in two regions from 0.80
MeV to 2.10 MeV and from 2.33 MeV to 4.39  MeV  were
read  from experimental points,  which were not able
to be resolved,  with the constant step of 0.13 MeV.
Main  features  of  the  experimental neutron energy
spectrum were conserved.
Data from Fig.5 of CJP,53,786,1975.

to 5.22 MeV  were  read  from  experimental  points,
which were not able to be resolved,with the constant
step of 0.13 MeV.  Main features of the experimental
neutron energy spectrum were conserved.
Data from Fig.5 of CJP,53,786,1975.

to 5.61 MeV  were  read  from  experimental  points,
which  were  not  able  to  be  resolved,  with  the
constant step of 0.13  MeV.  Main  features  of  the

experimental neutron energy spectrum were conserved.

By the compiler: the data were read from experimental
points, which were not able to be resolved, with the
constant  step  of  0.13  MeV.  Main features of the
experimental neutron energy spectrum were conserved.
Data from Fig.6 of CJP,53,786,1975.
By the compiler: the data were read from experimental
points, which were not able to be resolved, with the
constant step of 0.13  MeV.  Main  features  of  the
experimental neutron energy spectrum were conserved.
Data from Fig.6 of CJP,53,786,1975.
For each  endpoint energy a spectrum of photoneutrons
from deuterium was  obtained.  After  conversion  of
each  of  the  deuterium  spectra  to the efficiency
corrected  energy  spectra,  the   shapes   of   the
bremsstrahlungs    intensity    distributions   were
determined by dividing them by  the  deuteron  cross
section. By dividing the O-18 neutron spectra by the
corresponding  bremsstrahlung   distributions,   the
pseudoground  state  cross  sections  were  obtained
using Q-value of 8.05 MeV for the ground  state.  To
obtain  the  ground state cross section only the tip
region of 1 MeV of each spectrum was used.  The  tip
regions  of  the  pseudoground  state cross sections
were combined  to  obtain  the  ground  state  cross
section as a function of excitation energy.
Excitation energy after emission of neutron.
Data from Fig. 7 of CJP,53,786,1975.
The cross section to  the  first  excited  state  was
extracted  from  the  data  by first multiplying the
ground  state  cross  section  by  each   successive
bremsstrahlung distribution.  This produced a set of
normalized neutron spectra ( containing  the  ground
state   contribution   only).  Subtraction  of  each
spectrum from  the  corresponding  measured  neutron
spectrum   extracted   neutron   contributions  from
transitions to the excited states.  Division by  the
respective   bremsstrahlung  distributions  produced
pseudo excited cross sections when a Q-value of 8.92
MeV was used.  The first excited state cross section
was then determined following the same procedure  as
for the ground state cross section, but using here a
tip region of 1.6 MeV.
Excitation energy after emission of
neutron.
Data from Fig. 7 of CJP,53,786,1975.
